intro: Scleropogon longisetus, commonly known as the long-hairy sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant belonging to the Cyperaceae family. It is characterized by its slender, grass-like stems and narrow, linear leaves that are often covered with dense, silky hairs. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers arranged in spikes, typically blooming in late summer. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wet meadows, marshes, and along stream banks. Scleropogon longisetus plays a role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for various invertebrates.
